channel.title: Leonardo Tamiano - Youtube EN
channel.description: Aggiornamenti e metadati sui video caricati

item.title: Introduction to Web Exploitation
item.description:
Hi, and welcome to this new video!

In this video I introduce the most important ideas, topics and tools that are related to Web Exploitation. Specifically, in the video I discuss the main components of the web and how they all come to interact together to form web applications.

If you're interested in more videos of the series please let me know!

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

00:00 Introduction
02:20 Clients and Servers
04:20 The HTTP Protocol
08:30 HTML
13:43 CSS
15:40 JavaScript and the DOM
19:43 Web Applications
25:50 Overview so far
27:30 HTTP is stateless
29:40 On Malicious HTTP requests
32:22 Introduction to BurpSuite
36:46 Using BurpSuite
44:45 A first vulnerability
49:25 Conclusion

-------------------------

REFERENCES

- Material: https://github.com/LeonardoE95/yt-en/tree/main/src/2024-02-14-web-exploitation-introduction
- SecureBank: https://github.com/ssrdio/SecureBank


-------------------------

CONTACTS

- Blog: https://blog.leonardotamiano.xyz/
- Github: https://github.com/LeonardoE95?tab=repositories
- Support: https://www.paypal.com/donate/?hosted_button_id=T49GUPRXALYTQ

item.title: Enigma Machine in C – Part 1/3 – Overview
item.description:
Hi, and welcome to this video!

This is the first video of a small series of videos in which I will show how to implement the enigma machine using the C programming language.

The Enigma Machine is an electro-mechanical device that implements an extremely complex substitution cipher. That is, it works by using electricity, but it also has parts that move mechanically. This machine was used by the forces of the Axis during the Second World War in order to protect their communications.

Given that the machine has many different parts, I've decided to split this project into three different videos. In the first one I will give an overview of the machine and I will explain in depth the internals of the machine. In the second video we will implement the core library, and in the third and final video we will implement a simple CLI that will allow us to interface with our enigma machine.

I hope you find the video interesting, and if you have some feedback, please leave it in the comments down below!

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

00:00 Introduction
05:15 How to use Enigma
11:30 Substitution Ciphers
22:20 Enigma Internals
34:22 Plugboard
38:32 Reflector
42:11 Rotor
49:30 Double Step
53:22 Conclusion

-------------------------

REFERENCES

- Material: https://github.com/LeonardoE95/yt-en/tree/main/src/2024-02-10-from-scratch-enigma-machine-overview
Code: https://github.com/LeonardoE95/enigma-machine
Blog post: https://blog.leonardotamiano.xyz/tech/enigma-machine-c/
Enigma Historical Configuration: https://www.cryptomuseum.com/crypto/enigma/
Double Step Mechanism: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hcVhQeZ5gI4


-------------------------

CONTACTS

- Github: https://github.com/LeonardoE95?tab=repositories
- Support: https://www.paypal.com/donate/?hosted_button_id=T49GUPRXALYTQ

item.title: Pseudo-Randomness – Breaking LCG
item.description:
Hi everyone and welcome to this new video!

In this video I show how to break the Linear Congruential Generator, which is one one of the simplest form of pseudo-random number generators you can use.

Whenever you need to generate unpredictable numbers, remember to not use an LCG, because if you do, an attacker, by extracting few consecutive outputs, can easily predict the successive numbers your generator will output.

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

00:00 Introduction
01:44 On Pseudo-Random Number Generators
09:55 Breaking PRNGs
12:50 Linear Congruential Generator
14:00 LCG in GLIBC
21:55 Custom LCG in python
22:44 Breaking LCG
28:00 Code to break LCG
29:45 Careful with overflows

-------------------------

REFERENCES

- Material: https://github.com/LeonardoE95/yt-en/tree/main/src/2024-02-07-pseudo-randomness-breaking-lcg
- Material: https://github.com/LeonardoE95/yt-en/tree/main/src/2024-02-07-pseudo-randomness-breaking-lcg
- Original lecture: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i6z2Fp0iEbE
- GLIC code: https://ftp.gnu.org/gnu/libc/glibc-2.36.tar.bz2

-------------------------

CONTACTS

- Github: https://github.com/LeonardoE95?tab=repositories

item.title: Linux Privilege Escalation – PATH Hijacking
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

In this video I explained the idea behind PATH hijacking, a common technique for doing privilege escalation in linux machines. During the video I discuss the role of the PATH, and how it can be abused against vulnerable programs to perform privilege escalation.

Now, the same technique also works in windows, because windows also has a PATH variable. So, while in this video I focus on linux, remember that this same attack can work in other OSes, because the concept of the PATH is sort of universal at this point.

If you found the video interesting please support me by subscribing to the channel, and leave any feedback you have in the comments.

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

00:00 Introduction
01:10 What is the PATH?
07:30 How is the PATH used?
15:00 Example of a vulnerable program
22:55 PATH hijacking
25:40 Conclusion

-------------------------

REFERENCES

- Material: https://github.com/LeonardoE95/yt-en/tree/main/src/2024-01-31-linux-privesc-path-hijacking
https://github.com/LeonardoE95/yt-en/blob/main/src/2024-01-31-linux-privesc-path-hijacking

-------------------------

item.title: Teaching material
item.description:
The handling of material is a crucial aspect of teaching.

In this video I briefly talk about a solution which I'm trying right now on both my youtube channels (italian and english) in order to manage the material I create for the various videos. The final solution is a git repository that is then uploaded to github. The repository contains a table of videos with useful metadata. Then, for each video, we have a specific folder that contains the material for that video.

The repository is generated semi-automatically using Emacs and org-mode. In the video I briefly discuss how it works behind the scenes. If you are interested in more, please let me know and I will create a more in-depth video about it. The repository discussed is linked in the references.

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

00:00 Introduction
00:40 Structure of the repository
03:33 How I manage the data
08:00 How I generate the git repository
10:40 Conclusion

-------------------------

REFERENCES

- Material: https://github.com/LeonardoE95/yt-en/tree/main/src/2024-01-19-channel-teaching-material
https://github.com/LeonardoE95/yt-en

-------------------------

- Github: https://github.com/LeonardoE95?tab=repositories

item.title: From Scratch – Caesar Cipher in Python
item.description:
In this video I show how to implement a simple caesar cipher utility in python. The Caesar cipher represents one of the first historical cipher used by humans in order to protect their information.

If you're interested in more videos of the series please let me know, and if you're interested in the final code, checkout the link in the description.

-------------------------

item.title: HTB Bashed 2/2 – Report
item.description:
In this video I show how to write a penetration testing report detailing the Bashed HTB machine. During the report we analyze the various vulnerabilities that allowed us to complete the machine.

You can find the final report, both the source code (org-mode file), as well as the final artifact (pdf file) within the github repository linked in the description. You will also find a link that points to the report utility used throughout the video in order to generate the final artifact.

If you are interested in more content like this, please let me know and subscribe to the channel!

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

03:50 Starting the report
04:57 Summary section
17:33 Flags
18:40 Foothold section

25:40 Vulnerability 2 – Critical code was left on the server
28:00 Pivoting section
28:55 Vulnerability 3 – Sudoers does not require password
32:35 Privilege Escalation section

item.title: Conference Review – M0lecon 2023
item.description:
In this video I review the experience of joining the m0lecon 2023 conference in Turin, Italy.

The conference was filled with extremely fascinating contributions by various authors. For each talk, I will go over the main idea of the talk and leave some references so that if you are interested in the subject you can explore it yourself. The resouces section for this video is thus sub-divided by the specific talk in order to keep everything organized.

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

00:00 Introduction
01:07 Talk n.1 – Rowhammer: The Power of Bitflips
06:21 Talk n.2 – Developments in Isogeny-based Cryptography
12:44 Talk n.3 – FloatZone: A surprisping application of floating point additions
19:05 Talk n.4 – Web Session Integrity Vulnerabilities
22:25 Talk n.5 – Virtualbox N-day vm escape exploit
23:23 Talk n.6 – PyJails in the Wild: Bringing CTF Challenges to the Real World

-------------------------

REFERENCES

item.title: Scientific Review – The Impact of Code Patterns on the Security Testing of Web Applications
item.description:
In this video I read a scientific paper that came out last year on the topic of code auditing for web application backend code.
If you are interested in this content, where we analyze in-depth modern scientific research regarding computer security, let me know!

The authors of the paper introduced a novel way of thinking about residual risks when using code analyzers in the context of static application security testing (SAST). In particular, the authors introduced the notion of "testability tarpit" as a specific pattern of code that is known to cause problems for a class of static analysis tools. When these tools analyze a given piece of code, depending on how the code is written, they might find more or less difficulty to follow what is going on in the code in order to detect potential injection vulnerabilities. By analyzing how many such patterns are present in a given codebase, it is possible to gain more awareness on how to interpret the results of the SAST tools used within that same codebase.

The authors focused on the PHP and JavaScript languages, and in particular they

- Created 200+ testability tarpits
- Measured the performance of 11 SAST tools on those patterns of code
- Implemented discovery rules for finding those pattern in the popular Joern framework
- Found new vulnerabilities by performing manual refactoring
- Found new vulnerabilities by performing automatic refactoring

All the work done by the authors is provided within a github project, link in the description.

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

00:00 Introduction
03:33 Scientific paper structure
05:50 Abstract
13:35 Testability tarpits
26:00 CVE-2011-3357
28:49 Approach overview
36:15 Part 1 – Pattern Creation with SAST tools performance
39:45 Part 2 – Pattern Discovery with Joern
40:26 Part 3 – Pattern Transformation
40:45 Limitations
44:26 Related Work
45:30 Conclusion and Future Work

-------------------------

REFERENCES

- Material: https://github.com/LeonardoE95/yt-en/tree/main/src/2023-12-13-research-paper-testability-tarpits
Paper link: https://www.ndss-symposium.org/ndss-paper/auto-draft-206/
Github project: https://github.com/enferas/TestabilityTarpits
Joern: https://joern.io/

-------------------------

CONTACTS

- Blog: https://blog.leonardotamiano.xyz/
- Github: https://github.com/LeonardoE95?tab=repositories

item.title: Transistors – CS Foundations
item.description:
In this second episode we will explore the idea of the transistor. In particular, I will try to answer some of the following questions

- Why do we need transistors?
- What is a transistor?
- How do you build digital bits?
- How do you go from transistors to modern hardware architectures?

If you like the series, please let me know and I will keep making videos on it.
The plan is to cover the most foundamental idea you need to understand if you want to learn how to understand and talk to computers.

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

01:20 Review so far
03:10 How to Discretize the World
07:10 The Transistor – Theory
17:25 The Transistor – Practice
23:22 Towards Modern Hardware Architectures
30:33 Conclusion and References

item.title: From Scratch – Hexdump in C
item.description:
Hi, everyone, and welcome to this new series called "Programming From Scratch". The objective of this series will be to showcase how to build simple and educational software using bare minimals tools, without any extra libraries or frameworks.

In this first video I show how to implement a simple hexdump-like utility which can be used to dump the bytes of a given file in the hexadecimal format.

If you're interested in more videos of the series please let me know, and if you're interested in the final code, checkout the link in the description.

-------------------------

item.title: Introduction to TLS
item.description:
TLS, acronym for Transport Layer Security, is one of the most important network protocol when it comes to protecting the web of today. Introduced in 1995 under the different name of SSL by the Netscape company, TLS has seen a complex and intricate evolution over the years. It was in 1999 when SSL changed its name to TLS, after a re-branding done by the IETF, the institution responsible for standardizing the protocols that make up the internet.

In this video we introduce the main idea behind TLS. In particular we will talk about the core cryptographic services that TLS provides, the big ideas behind the design of the protocol, and we will see a specific pcap trace captured by going to my website using HTTPs, which is HTTP over a TLS session. In future videos I will go in more depth over various topics related to TLS and I will showcase in detail various attacks that were done to TLS.

I hope it is enjoyable to watch, in case let me know and, if you find it interesting, feel free to subscribe to support my project here on youtube.

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

00:00 Introduction
02:15 The CIA triad
09:50 History of SSL/TLS
15:50 Core ideas in TLS design
20:00 TLS Handshake
27:25 TLS Encryption
33:30 Cipher suites
35:30 Extensions
36:50 Example: PCAP trace
46:35 Attacks to TLS

-------------------------

REFERENCES

- Material: https://github.com/LeonardoE95/yt-en/tree/main/src/2023-09-20-tls-introduction-to-tls
IETF Data Tracker on TLS: https://datatracker.ietf.org/group/tls/about/

-------------------------

item.title: OSCP Guide: My Exam Experience
item.description:
The OSCP (Offensive Security Certified Professional) is one of the most sought out certification offered by Offensive Security. In this video I will talk about my exam experience, and in general about the experience that I had while preparing for the certification.

During my preparation I have developed a cheatsheet, which I have made available for anyone at the git repository linked below. I suggest you take a look at it if you're also preparing for the certification.

In the future I will make more videos regarding OSCP and I will enter into more technical details regarding the content taught by the course and the final exam itself.
